climbs.name: What a Drag it is Getting Old
climbs.fa: project  (this one is open for FFA, have at it!)

content.description: Crux starts at bolt 4 and only eases slightly until the final slab. Intriguing moves require core body strength as well as fingers. At least one strong climber has powered through the cruxes only to slip and fall on the 5.10 friction slab at the top!
content.location: Look for the obvious bolted route left of the Original Route.

content.description: Pitch 1 (5.11+): 2 bolt slab start to steeper and more protected cruxy moves to a rest, then jam up a sparsely bolted crack (bring gear from .4-4 if you want to sew it up or skip the bolts) to a ledge and chains. Pitch 2: 5.10 warmup crack to a v6 boulder problem through the bulge, finishing with steep face moves to the chains.
content.protection: 12 draws, 70m rope, tape or jammies. I decided to bolt the crack to avoid the rack, flared cams, and soft rock. Climb it, and be the judge.
content.location: This route is on the next buttress upstream from the Rest Home but uses the same parking area. Look up and see the crack line going through two tiers of rock. The approach starts at a pine tree a hundred or so feet up the road from the parking lot, takes 15 minutes or so.

climbs.name: Seniors Rule
climbs.fa: the professor and Jerry Kokotailo, October 2014

content.description: The route traverses above a substantial roof and goes up the arete. Airy! A bit sandy at the start and at the honeycomb ledge below the crux pockets.
content.protection: 10 bolts to get to the chain anchor. Use a full size sling on bolt 3 to avoid rope drag.
content.location: The approach path ends near this climb. Look for bolts to the right of the big, ugly, dirty corner.

climbs.name: Project
climbs.fa: aided/bolted in 2017 (please reserve the FFA for the team that prepared the route)

content.description: This will be a second pitch to either Original Route or What a Drag it is Getting Old. As of 2017, the route has only been toproped once. The exit move to the anchor ledge seems quite hard. It may be possible to push it past the ledge onto the upper wall proper....
content.location: Starts from the anchor shared by What a Drag it is Getting Old and Original Route (climb one of those two first).

content.description: Crux is getting from the final bolt to the chains and involves some thought.
content.protection: 2 bolts, a solid fixed pin, then three more bolts to a chain anchor on a small sloping ledge.
content.location: The approach path ends at this route. Look for bolts a few feet left of the big, ugly, dirty corner.

content.description:
This was the first route on the wall. Details of its history are sparse (see comments below). The only evidence at the site is a two-bolt anchor with homemade angle iron hangers and thick perlon connecting the hangers to a a steel US Army carabiner (subsequently backed up with a locking aluminum biner).

Although dirty with some loose pieces, the route is better (and harder) than it looks. There is a physical crux in the middle of the flare, after which the quality improves. The final undercling flake is quite good.
content.protection: Bring nuts and cams (including a #4 Camalot or #5 Friend)
content.location: At the approach path terminus, move left about 50 feet until you reach the base of a dirty flare which constitutes the start of the climb.

climbs.name: Grandma, Pick Up the Phone!
climbs.fa: project  (please don't "steal" the FFA from the route cleaners/bolters)

content.description: Several cruxes, but the most difficult is reaching and pulling past the "telephone handset" near the top.
content.protection: 7 bolts to a small sloping ledge. To descend, traverse right 6 feet to the chain anchor of Over the Hill and rappel or lower.
content.location: Close to the approach path terminus; immediately left of Over the Hill
